snippet: The ruling strikes down a law, enacted after 2006 terrorist attacks in London and Madrid, that required telecommunications companies to keep information about calls and emails.
abstract: European Court of Justice strikes down European Union law, adopted in response to deadly terrorist attacks, that requires telecommunications companies to retain information about calls and emails for up to two years.
lead_paragraph: The ruling strikes down a law, enacted after 2006 terrorist attacks in London and Madrid, that required telecommunications companies to keep information about calls and emails.

headline.main: European Court Rejects Data Retention Rules, Citing Privacy
headline.print_headline: European Court Cites Privacy in Rejecting Data Law
